reviewText: A great addition to anyone 's music library. This is as I remember him when I saw him perform with BST the last time.
Title: N/A

reviewText: Thomas had a fantastic voice when he first started singing with BSandT at the age of 27. At the time of this DVD he was 65 and yes the voice has aged considerably. Even so he turns in an energetic, personable performance along with an excellent band of players. For a good presentation of a younger voiced Thomas, four songs on the 20 Years After Woodstock Reunion DVD from 89 captures Thomas in still youthful, if not prime, voice. Surprisingly BS and T were the second highest paid performers at Woodstock.

reviewText: DAVID CLAYTON THOMAS have always the same voice... from the BS & T time. Great performance,  great voice, very good sound and camera shots.Two hours of wonderfull music ! Magic moments with the Montreal Jubilation Choir. You can buy this DVD "les yeux fermés" (closed eyes : because no problème >> it's GREAT !) Thanks Mr DCT

reviewText: DCT does NOT disappoint!  This was incredibly well put together and reflects the overall vocal strength of DCT that still maintains.  I would highly recommend this and a must see.  There is also extras for selection that has a great interview of the start of his career and his rise through BS&Ts.;Enjoy this treasure while you can!

reviewText: If you liked Blood Sweat and Tears, you've hear his voice.  David Clayton Thomas is older in this video, but he is an entertainer.  It has become a favorite video of mine.  The seller is very good too!

reviewText: I enjoyed this concert very much.  My only criticism is that he has so many more songs that one concert just doesn't cover his body of work.  I always loved his music when he fronted Blood Sweat & Tears and was happy he sang many of those songs.  Well worth the price of the DVD.
summary: David Clayton Thomas is a Legend, and he still has it!

reviewText: Four and a Half BIG Stars!!! David Clayton-Thomas, arguably the greatest Blood, Sweat, & Tears lead vocalist, revisits those great Grammy-winning days of jazz, rock, blues, and ballad hits produced by one of rock's greatest instrumentally-charged groups, and he adds in hits from his own solo singing career. None of the other BS&T stars are here at this live performance at the Montreal Jazz Festival in 2006, but DC-T is riding a tight, pumped-up band of brass, reeds, woodwinds, and percussion, with a dash of electronics. David's inimitable dramatic voice is MAGNIFICENT, as is his control of nuance and dynamics: the clock has not ticked for this great voice. Classics like "Spinning Wheel" , "You've Made Me So Very Happy", "Go Down Gamblin' ", and "God Bless the Child" are wonderful recollections of the BS&T days. And DC-T's own "You're The One" is breath-taking beauty. But the rousing performance that steals the show, even from the wonderful gospel choir at the end, is composer Steve Winwood's wild and weird "Forty Thousand Headmen": great vocals, soaring orchestral playing, and great Bruce Cassidy electronic solos with a slick arrangement riffing off the original BS&T recording. Only a badly-miked tenor sax solo kept this one from perfection, but those things happen on live shows. Thomas takes the original arrangements, adds different vocal nuances, and plugs in super-charged instrumental solos: exactly what most of us will want. And he delivers, BIG TIME: Highly Recommended to all and ABSOLUTELY ESSENTIAL for Blood, Sweat, and Tears fans. Four and a Half HUGE Stars!! (DVD, color, NTSC-all regions, 120 minutes with David Clayton-Thomas interview)
summary: DAVID CLAYTON-THOMAS IN A GREAT "BS&T"-INFLUENCED LIVE PERFORMANCE
